docs.title: 1. Workflow Trigger
docs.text:
• The pipeline runs when either:

  • You push code to server-deploy branch

  • OR a Pull Request is opened toward server-deploy

docs.title: 2. Checkout Repository
docs.text: • GitHub Actions pulls your repository code into the CI environment so workflows can run on it.

docs.title: 3. Setup Node.js
docs.text: • This step installs Node.js version 22.20.0 inside the GitHub Actions runner.

docs.title: 4. Install Dependencies
docs.text:
• Runs:
  • npm install
  • This installs all project dependencies required for building/testing.

docs.title: 5. Run Test Cases
docs.text:
Executes:

  • npm test

docs.title: 6. Test Result Decision
docs.text:
If tests pass → workflow is marked SUCCESS

If tests fail → workflow stops and marks FAILURE

docs.title: 7. End Workflow
docs.text:
Pipeline ends after success or failure.

docs.title: 1. Start CD Workflow
docs.text: • The deployment workflow begins.

docs.title: 2. Event Triggered?
docs.text:
• The workflow checks if a specific event has happened.

  • The workflow is triggered when either:

  • Push to server-deploy branch

  • Pull Request (PR) to server-deploy branch

  • If yes → continue to deployment.

docs.title: 3. Deploy to EC2
docs.text: • Once the event triggers, GitHub Actions logs into your EC2 using SSH and starts running deployment commands.

docs.title: Command:
docs.text:
• git pull origin server-deploy

  • Your EC2 instance will:

  • Fetch the latest code from the server-deploy branch

  • Update the local project folder with new changes

docs.title: Command:
docs.text:
• npm install
  • All dependency is installed

docs.title: Command:
docs.text:
• if server is not running

  • pm2 start src/app.js --name elearning-backend

OR

  • If the app is already running:

  • pm2 restart elearning-backend

This ensures:

  • Your latest code is now running

  • The backend server restarts without downtime

docs.title: 7. Deployment Completed
docs.text: The workflow reports success.

docs.title: 8. End Workflow
docs.text:
The CD pipeline finishes.

The Entity–Relationship Diagram (ERD) represents the logical structure of the ELMS database. It defines the entities, their attributes, and the relationships among them to ensure data integrity, consistency, and efficient querying.

This design supports features such as:

  • User authentication and role-based access
  • Course enrollment and tracking

docs.title: Project Overview
docs.text:
The E-Learning Management System (ELMS) is a web-based platform built using the (Postgresql, Express.js, React.js, Node.js)**. It is designed to make online learning simple, accessible, and effective for learners of all levels. The platform allows users to access free learning documentation created by instructors and professionals.

This system aims to bridge the gap between learners seeking structured educational content and instructors who wish to share their knowledge in a digital environment.

docs.title: Objective
docs.text:
The main objective of the E-Learning Management System is to provide a learning platform that allows users to:

  • Access free educational content.
  • Learn through step-by-step documentation .

docs.title: 1. Provide Structured Learning Paths
docs.text: Organize content into clear, progressive modules that guide learners from beginner to advanced levels.

docs.title: 2. Offer Free Documentation
docs.text: Enable learners to read free, high-quality documentation to gain conceptual clarity.

docs.title: 3. Ensure Smooth User Experience
docs.text: Deliver a responsive, fast, and interactive learning environment across all devices.

docs.title: Authentication Phase
docs.text: • When a user visits the platform, they must register or log in.

docs.title: During registration:
docs.text:
• User provides details like name, email, and password.

  • Passwords are hashed using bcrypt and stored securely in the database.

  • Each user is assigned a role (e.g., user or admin).

docs.title: During login:
docs.text:
• Credentials are validated.

  • If valid, the system generates a JWT (JSON Web Token) token for identity verification.

docs.title: Authorization Phase
docs.text:
• Once authenticated, the system checks the user’s role:

  • <User Role> : Gets access to user features like viewing courses, adding to My Courses, and reading documentation.

  • <Admin Role>: Redirected to the Admin Dashboard where they can manage courses and users.

  • Every subsequent API call or page request uses the JWT token to verify permissions before granting access.

docs.title: Security Highlights
docs.text:
<Password Hashing> : Protects user credentials.

<Token-based Authentication>: Ensures session security without storing sensitive data on the client.

<Role-based Authorization>: Prevents unauthorized users from accessing admin functionalities.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: This architecture illustrates how the E-Learning Management System (ELMS) is hosted on Amazon Web Services (AWS) to ensure scalability, security, and high availability. It leverages AWS core components such as VPC, EC2, and RDS to manage application and database layers efficiently.

docs.title: 1. User
docs.text:
• The end-user accesses the application through a web browser or client interface.
  • All requests are directed to the application server hosted on AWS.

docs.title: 2. Amazon Cloud
docs.text:
• Represents the entire AWS infrastructure used to deploy and manage cloud services.
  • Provides reliability, scalability, and global accessibility.

docs.title: 3. Virtual Private Cloud (VPC)
docs.text:
• A secure isolated network within AWS where resources (like EC2 and RDS) are hosted.
  • Ensures complete control over network configuration, IP addressing, and access control.

docs.title: 4. Private Subnet
docs.text:
• The private area of the VPC where critical backend resources are kept safe from the public internet.
  • Contains the EC2 instance (server) and RDS database for internal communication only.

docs.title: 5. Amazon EC2 (Elastic Compute Cloud)
docs.text:
• Acts as the application server.
  • Hosts the Node.js + Express backend for the ELMS.
  • Handles business logic, authentication, and API endpoints.
  • Communicates securely with the RDS database in the private subnet.

docs.title: 6. Amazon RDS (Relational Database Service)
docs.text:
• Hosts the PostgreSQL database for storing all user, course.
  • Managed service — handles backups, scaling, and availability automatically.
  • Accessible only from the EC2 instance inside the same private subnet.

docs.title: Workflow Summary
docs.text:
1. The user sends a request to the application.
  2. The request reaches the EC2 instance running the backend.
  3. The EC2 instance processes the request and, if needed, interacts with Amazon RDS (PostgreSQL).
  4. The processed response is returned to the user via the internet.

docs.title: Benefits of This Architecture
docs.text: Feature Description Scalability Easily scale EC2 and RDS instances based on traffic. Security Private subnet and VPC ensure isolated access control. Reliability Managed AWS services reduce downtime risk. Performance Optimized communication between EC2 and RDS within the same VPC. Ease of Management AWS handles infrastructure, backups, and monitoring.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: This AWS setup provides a secure, scalable, and efficient environment for deploying the E-Learning Management System (ELMS). It ensures that the application remains responsive and protected, even as usage grows.

docs.title: Data Flow Diagram (DFD)
docs.text: The Data Flow Diagram (DFD) illustrates how data moves through the E-Learning Management System (ELMS) — from users and admins to backend processes and database entities. It visually represents the interaction between external entities, processes, and data stores, helping to understand how the system functions as a whole.

docs.title: Level 0 – Context Diagram
docs.text:
At the highest level, the ELMS consists of two main external entities:

  • User: Learns, enrolls in courses
  • Admin: Manages users, courses, and monitors system activity.

Both interact with the system’s central processes through a secure authentication mechanism.

docs.title: External Entities
docs.text: Entity Description User The learner who registers, logs in, enrolls in courses, Admin The system administrator who manages courses

docs.title: Processes
docs.text: Process Description P1 – User Authentication Handles user and admin login/registration. Validates credentials and fetches role-based access data from the database. P2 – Course Management Allows admins to update, or delete courses, and enables users to view or search available courses. P3 – User Course Management Manages course enrollment. Tracks which users are enrolled in which courses. P4 – Admin Dashboard Displays analytics like total users, courses for the admin panel.

docs.title: Data Stores
docs.text: Data Store Description D1 – Users Contains all registered users’ information (name, email, password, etc.). D2 – Roles Stores role types such as Admin, Student, etc. D3 – Courses Holds course details like title, description, and duration. D4 – Users_Courses Maps users to their enrolled courses (many-to-many relationship). D5 – User_Roles Links users to their assigned roles for role-based access control.

docs.title: Data Flow Summary
docs.text:
1. The User or Admin logs in via the Authentication process.
  2. The system validates credentials and fetches role-based details.
  3. The Admin can manage courses and view statistics.
  4. The User can browse courses, enroll
  5. All actions update or fetch data from corresponding data stores.
  6. The Dashboard provides summarized data to the Admin.

docs.title: Conclusion
docs.text: The Data Flow Diagram for ELMS helps visualize the interaction between users, admins, and the system’s backend processes. It ensures a clear understanding of how data is handled securely, efficiently, and accurately throughout the application lifecycle.

docs.title: Problem
docs.text:
In today’s fast-paced digital learning environment, many learners prefer to study independently and at their own pace. However, they face several challenges when relying solely on online resources:

  • Unstructured Learning: Many websites or platforms provide scattered or incomplete information, making it difficult to follow a structured learning path.

  • No Personalized Space: Most free resources do not allow learners to track their progress or organize their learning journey.

These limitations make self-learning time-consuming and sometimes discouraging, especially for beginners who seek step-by-step, beginner-friendly explanations.

docs.title: Solution
docs.text:
The E-Learning Management System (ELMS) addresses these problems by providing a centralized and structured learning platform focused entirely on free documentation-based learning.

Key aspects of the solution include:

  • Free and Accessible Learning Content: Learners can access well-structured documentation on various technical topics without any cost barriers.

  • Beginner-Friendly Explanations: Each topic is written in a clear, simple, and step-by-step manner so that even newcomers can understand complex concepts easily.

  • Organized Course Flow: Documentation is divided into topics and subtopics, allowing users to follow a logical learning sequence.

  • User Dashboard: Each learner can maintain their own profile and add courses.

  • Responsive Interface: The website is fully responsive, ensuring that learners can read and study from any device—desktop, tablet, or mobile.

docs.title: Overview
docs.text: The E-Learning Management System (ELMS) allows users to learn through free documentation . The system provides role-based access where users can explore and enroll in courses, while admins can manage all course-related operations.

docs.title: 1.1 Login / Register
docs.text:
• New users can register or log in using their credentials.
  • Upon successful login, the system identifies the user's role:
  • User
  • Admin
  • Passwords are securely hashed and stored in the database.

docs.title: 2.1 View All Courses
docs.text:
• After logging in, a user can view all available courses listed on the website.
  • Each course card displays:
  • Course title
  • Description
  • view free documentation or add the course to “My Courses”.

docs.title: 2.2 Access Free Documentation
docs.text: • Users can click on the “Free Documentation” button to read course material for free.

docs.title: 2.3 Add to My Courses
docs.text:
• Users can add interesting courses to My Courses.
  • Once added, courses appear in the My Courses section for future access.

docs.title: 2.4 Search to Courses
docs.text: • User Can search specific Course on the basis of Course Name(Index)

docs.title: Profile Section
docs.text: • User Can see his/her email,name

docs.title: My Courses Section
docs.text:
• Displays all courses a user has added.
  • Allows viewing documentation.

docs.title: Search to My Courses
docs.text: • User Can search specific My Course on the basis of Course Name(Index)

docs.title: 3.1 Access Admin Panel
docs.text:
• Admins are redirected to the Admin Dashboard after login.
  • The dashboard provides a full overview of available courses and management actions.

docs.title: 3.2 Add Course
docs.text: • Admin can add new course

docs.title: 3.3 Edit Existing Course
docs.text: • Admins can modify existing course details:

docs.title: 3.4 Delete Course
docs.text: • Admins can delete courses permanently.

docs.title: 3.5 Dashboard
docs.text:
• Admin Will be able to see total courses
  • Admin will be able to see total users

docs.title: 4. Summary
docs.text: The E-Learning Management System (ELMS) ensures an easy learning experience for students and efficient course management for admins through a role-based interactive dashboard.

docs.title: Use Case Diagram
docs.text: The Use Case Diagram visually represents how different actors (users and administrators) interact with the E-Learning Management System (ELMS). It helps in understanding the system’s functionality from the user's perspective — what actions they can perform and how each process is connected.

docs.title: Actors:
docs.text:
• User: Can register, log in, browse courses, manage enrolled courses
  • Admin: Manages courses, monitors user activity, and maintains overall system data.

docs.title: Major Use Cases:
docs.text:
• Authentication: Handles user login and registration.
  • Course Management: Allows updating, and deleting courses (admin) and viewing or enrolling (user).
  • Profile & Dashboard: Users can view/edit their profiles.

docs.title: Diagram:
docs.text: The diagram above provides a high-level overview of the system interactions, making it easier to identify the roles, process flow, and system boundaries in the application.
